29 August 1952
Mr, Graydon iAusmus
WUOA, University of Alabama
University, Alabama
Dear Graydont
Your memo of August 26 arrived this morning and I hasten to
send the first portion of my reply to it.
First — for the record ~ let me say that I of course accept
the general proposition which you outline, I'his you knew, but I am
putting it down in black and white so that you have it on the record.
Second, I would favor choosing someone on the first level —
that is the "top-level, high-caliber man,11 rather than someone on
the second level.
As to the nominating committee, I have a few suggestions for it,
I am not considering Siegel or Wheatley as I assume they are out of
the country and not available; if either of them were available, I
would list them among the possible members of such a committee.
Other members — in addition to you — would be Gaines, Miller, and
Hull, If you wanted to supplement this by someone from outside the
board of directors, I would suggest McCarty or Levenson, Mac is
unquestionably our “elder statesman" and his advice would certainly
be helpful; and from what I’ve seen of Levenson, he is a very able
person who would probably know people in the educational world better
than most of the rest of us.
In view of his frequent protestations of disinclination to work
too hard or too intensively on special assignments I think that Waldo
should not be included on the committee. And in view of his nomination
for the position I think that John Dunn should likewise be omitted.

I will give a good deal of thought to a list of names and shall
certainly come up with one before the committee meets.
As far as I’m concerned, the relationship which should be main¬
tained between the board and the executive director was adequately,
stated in the excerpts of the minutes which you attached to your
memorandum. I would supplement these by reference to the footnotes
as provided in those minutes; even though we did not adopt those
parts of the resolution as originally submitted, I think they should
be accepted as guidance.
Finally, whatever names are suggested by members of the board,
I think the canvassing committee should turn up a number on its own;
three men devoting several d; ys to this can do lots more than any
of us working along for a few hours—or minutes l
